revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = ClassDojo | logo = ClassDojo logo.png | type = [[Private company|Private]] | founded = August 2011 | founder = Sam Chaudhary
Liam Don | area_served = Worldwide | location = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | products = [[Educational technology]] | website = {{url|http://classdojo.com}} | num_employees = 30 (2017){{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kathleenchaykowski/2017/05/22/how-classdojo-built-one-of-the-most-popular-classroom-apps-by-listening-to-teachers/#3e96d1941e5e|title=How ClassDojo Built One of the Most Popular Classroom Apps by Listening to Teachers|publisher=Forbes|first=Kathleen|last=Chaykowski|date=May 22, 2017|access-date=August 4, 2017}} }} '''ClassDojo''' is a classroom communication app used to share reports between parents and teachers. Teachers track student behavior and upload photos or videos. The gamification style system teaches developmental skills through real-time feedback.{{cite web| url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/08/15/classdojo-launch-seed-funding/| title=ClassDojo Lands $1.6M From Paul Graham, Ron Conway To Help Teachers Control Their Classrooms|publisher=TechCrunch| author=Rip Empson| date=August 15, 2012| access-date=November 9, 2017}} The application, which has been translated into 35 languages, has been used in 180 countries and by 90% of the school districts in the United States.{{cite web| url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kathleenchaykowski/2017/05/22/how-classdojo-built-one-of-the-most-popular-classroom-apps-by-listening-to-teachers/#22a830201e5e| title=How ClassDojo Built One Of The Most Popular Classroom Apps By Listening To Teachers| author=Kathleen Chaykowski| date=May 22, 2017| access-date=November 9, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/ed-tech-startup-classdojo-is-going-viral-2016-7|title=A 'Very Non-Silicon Valley' Startup is Going Viral Among Teachers and Parents|publisher=Business Insider|first=Abby |last=Jackson|date=July 8, 2016 |access-date=August 4, 2017}}{{cite web| url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/05/08/mindfulness-schools/101447370/| title=Breathe Deeply: Mindfulness coming to a school near you| publisher=USA Today| author=Greg Toppo| date=May 8, 2017| access-date=November 9, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3066128/like-apples-airpods-dopplers-wireless-earbuds-got-delayed-heres-why|title=ClassDojo is Teaching Kids Empathy in 90% of K-8 Schools Nationwide|publisher=Fast Company|first=Ainsley|last=O'Connell|date=December 1, 2016|access-date=August 4, 2017}} ClassDojo was launched in August 2011 and was initially funded in the [[ImagineK12]] education [[seed accelerator]].{{Cite web|title = The edtech startup that's shucking the playbook by acting like a consumer company|url = https://pando.com/2014/03/12/the-edtech-startup-thats-shucking-the-playbook-by-acting-like-a-consumer-company/|website = [[PandoDaily]]|accessdate = August 8, 2015|last = DeAmicis|first = Carmel|date = March 12, 2014}}{{cite web | url = https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-03/21/class-dojo | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120814132609/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-03/21/class-dojo | website = [[Wired UK]] | first = Olivia | last = Solon | title = Startup of the week: ClassDojo | date = March 21, 2012 | accessdate = October 24, 2016 | archivedate = August 14, 2012 | deadurl = yes | df = }} == History == In August 2011, Sam Chaudhary and Liam Don moved to [[Palo Alto]], California, from the [[United Kingdom]] to launch ClassDojo after the startup was accepted in the first cohort of ImagineK12, a [[Y Combinator (company)|Y-combinator]] program and funding for education startups.{{cite web | url = http://www.cityam.com/article/insights-young-silicon-valley-startup | first = Philip | last = Salter | website = [[City A.M.]] | date = April 23, 2012 | title = Insights from a young Silicon Valley startup | accessdate = August 8, 2015}} In September 2011 the company released a [[Development stage|beta version]] of the platform.{{cite web | url = https://pando.com/2012/08/15/classdojo-raises-1-6m-announces-upcoming-iphone-and-ipad-apps/ | website = [[PandoDaily]] | accessdate = August 8, 2015 | first = Andrew | last = James | title = ClassDojo Raises $1.6M, Announces Upcoming iPhone and iPad Apps | date = August 15, 2012}} Within a year of launching, the platform had been used by 3.5 million teachers and students, in more than 30 countries.{{cite web | url = https://techcrunch.com/2012/08/15/classdojo-launch-seed-funding/ | website = [[TechCrunch]] | date = August 15, 2012 | accessdate = August 8, 2015 | last = Empson | first = Rip | title = ClassDojo Lands $1.6M From Paul Graham, Ron Conway To Help Teachers Control Their Classrooms }}{{cite web | url = https://thenextweb.com/insider/2012/08/15/classdojo-announces-1-6m-seed-funding-rolls-student-behaviour-improvement-platform-beta/| website = [[TheNextWeb]] | first = Paul | last = Sawers | accessdate = August 8, 2015 | date = August 15, 2012 | title = ClassDojo taps $1.6m in seed funding, as its student behaviour-improvement platform rolls out of beta }} In August 2012, ClassDojo announced it had raised $1.6 million of main [[Seed money|seed capital]] from [[Paul Graham (computer programmer)|Paul Graham]], SV Angel, [[SoftTech VC]], [[Mitch Kapor]], Lerer Ventures, and [[General Catalyst Partners]].{{cite web | url = https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/classdojo | website = [[Crunchbase]] | title = Crunchbase: ClassDojo | accessdate = August 8, 2015 }}{{cite web | url = https://venturebeat.com/2012/08/15/funding-daily-watch-out-for-spies-and-ninjas/ | title = Funding Daily: watch out for spies and ninjas | date = August 15, 2012 | accessdate = August 8, 2015 | first = Rebecca | last = Grant | website = [[VentureBeat]]}} In February 2013, ClassDojo released its first app for the [[Android (operating system)|Android]] operating system.{{cite web|url=http://www.avatargeneration.com/2013/02/classdojo-release-android-app/|title=ClassDojo Release Android App|publisher=Avatar Generation |date=February 28, 2013|access-date=August 4, 2017}} That same year, the company raised $8.5 million in a series A round of funding,{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/03/03/classdojo-raises-8-5m-to-put-digital-gold-stars-on-your-kids-digital-folder/|title=ClassDojo Raises $8.5M to Put Digital Gold Stars On Your Kid's Digital Folder|publisher=VentureBeat|first=Kia |last=Kokalitcheva|date=March 3, 2014 |access-date=August 4, 2017}} and began offering the platform in native languages other than English.{{cite web|url=http://betakit.com/classdojothe-worlds-fastest-growing-education-startup-launches-in-canada/|title=ClassDojo, The "World's Fastest Growing Education Startup", Launches in Canada|publisher=Betakit|first=Joseph |last=Czikk |date=September 23, 2013|access-date=August 4, 2017}} In 2014, ClassDojo added a messaging function to its platform, allowing teachers to communicate with parents as a group or directly.{{cite web|url=https://www.edsurge.com/news/2014-03-27-classdojo-announces-new-messaging-feature|title=ClassDojo Announces New Messaging Feature|publisher=EdSurge News|date=March 27, 2014|access-date=August 4, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://edtechreview.in/news/1518-simple-positive-communication-with-parents-made-easy-with-classdojo-messenger|title=Simple, Positive Communication With Parents Made Easy With ClassDojo Messenger|publisher=EdTech Review|first=Prasanna |last=Bharti|date=September 10, 2014|access-date=August 4, 2017}} ClassDojo added Class Story, a digital content stream created by class teachers and accessible by parents in August 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.edsurge.com/news/2015-08-05-classdojo-s-summer-updates-include-instagram-for-the-classroom|title=ClassDojo's Summer Updates Include 'Instagram for the Classroom'|publisher=EdSurge News|first=Tony |last=Wan|date=August 5, 2015|access-date=August 4, 2017}} In late 2015, the company raised $21 million in a series B round of funding led by [[General Catalyst Partners]].{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/04/15/classdojo-raises-21-million-for-app-to-make-parent-teacher-meetings-obsolete/|title=ClassDojo Raises $21 Million For App to Make Parent-Teacher Meetings Obsolete|publisher=TechCrunch|first=Lora |last=Kolodny|date=April 15, 2016|access-date=August 4, 2017}} In January 2016, ClassDojo partnered with [[Stanford University|Stanford University's]] Project for Education Research That Scales (PERTS) lab, to release a five-part series of educational videos discussing [[Mindset#Fixed mindset and growth mindset|growth mindset]].{{cite web|url=https://www.edsurge.com/news/2016-01-19-classdojo-s-critters-want-to-teach-you-about-growth-mindsets|title=ClassDojo's Critters Want to Teach You About Growth Mindsets|publisher=EdSurge News|first=Tony |last=Wan|date=January 19, 2016 |access-date=August 4, 2017}} In September 2016, it was reported that the series had been viewed by one of every four kids in American classrooms.{{cite web|url= http://qz.com/791388/meet-mojo-a-monster-stanford-helped-create-to-teach-your-kids-that-effort-matters-more-than-iq/|title=Meet Mojo, The Monster Stanford and Harvard Are Using to Teach Your Kids "Growth Mindset" and Empathy|publisher=Quartz|first=Jenny|last=Anderson|date=September 27, 2016|access-date=August 4, 2017}} That same year, the platform added School Story, the update enables school administration and teachers to share school-related content to all parents connected to the school,{{cite web|url=http://www.eschoolnews.com/2016/04/18/classdojo-expands-beyond-classrooms-to-whole-school-sharing/|title=ClassDojo Moves Beyond Classrooms to Whole School Sharing|publisher=eSchool News|date=April 18, 2016|access-date=August 4, 2017}} and Student Stories, a tool for students to manage their unique portfolios, interact with classmates and share their experiences with their parents.{{cite web|url=https://thejournal.com/articles/2016/07/20/classdojo-launches-parental-engagement-tool.aspx|title=ClassDojo Launches Parental Engagement Tool|publisher=The Journal|first=Joshua|last=Bolkan|date=July 20, 2016|access-date=August 4, 2017}} In October 2016, ClassDojo released a video series about empathy that it created in partnership with the Making Caring Common Project at [[Harvard Graduate School of Education]]. In May 2017, the company, in partnership with the Yale Center for Emotional Intelligence, released a mindfulness curriculum.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/05/08/mindfulness-schools/101447370/|title=Breathe Deeply: Mindfulness Coming to a School Near You|publisher=USA Today|first=Greg|last=Toppos|date=May 8, 2017|access-date=August 4, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://hechingerreport.org/mindful-tech-tool-can-help/|title=Be Mindful: How a Tech Tool Can Help|publisher=The Hechinger Report|first=Nichole|last=Dobo|date=May 10, 2017|access-date=August 4, 2017}} == Features and tools == The platform allows students, teachers and parents to connect, support and develop student skills.{{cite news | url = http://www.brainerddispatch.com/news/2012-09-14/tech-savvy-classroom | newspaper = [[Brainerd Dispatch]] | date = September 14, 2012 | first1= Jessi | last1 = Pierce | first2 = Phil | last2 = Seibel | title = Tech Savvy: In the classroom | accessdate = August 8, 2015}} To use the classroom communication program, teachers register to obtain a free account, and then create "classes" with their students. Students use the program initially with an access code; after creating an account, the students can customize avatars, see classes and see individual progress. Parents can also access ClassDojo when they are invited by the teachers, and can visualize the progress of the child and the information shared by the teachers. Teachers can reward students with positive feedback in real time when they show good exertion in a task or activity in [[Classroom|class]]. Teachers are also able to communicate directly with parents through the platform. The program is customizable, and the teachers can change the skills for which the students obtain [[feedback]] to adapt to the needs of the class or of the school. ClassDojo is available as a web application that can be used in any device with a web browser, and also with native applications for [[iPhone]] ([[iOS]]) and [[Android (operating system)|Android]]. The company plans to keep the main platform free for teachers. The founders say that it is because they want teachers, students and parents in all types of schools to use ClassDojo to encourage learning, skill development, and character-building.{{cite web | url = https://www.edsurge.com/n/2013-04-02-opinion-bridging-the-disconnect-between-teachers-and-the-edtech-industry | first = Shawn | last = Rubin | accessdate = August 8, 2015 | title = OPINION: Bridging the Disconnect Between Teachers and the Edtech Industry | date = April 2, 2013 | website = [[EdSurge]]}} == Platforms == ClassDojo is available as a web application that can be used on any device with a web browser, and also as a native application for iPhone and Android, with a website in HTML 5.2. The program can be viewed on any mobile device including Android, iOS, and other phones and tablets. == Recognition == In 2011, ClassDojo received the [[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today Show]]'s Education Innovation Award.{{cite web | first = Meghan | last = Casserly | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/meghancasserly/2012/12/17/30-under-30-the-millennials-overhauling-education-and-leaving-no-child-or-teacher-behind/ | title = 30 Under 30: The Millennials Overhauling Education And Leaving No Child (Or Teacher) Behind | date = December 17, 2012 | accessdate = August 8, 2015 | website = [[Forbes]] }}{{cite web | first = Tina | last = Barseghian | date = September 27, 2011 | title = Class Dojo Wins Innovation Challenge at Education Nation | accessdate = August 8, 2015 | url = http://ww2.kqed.org/mindshift/2011/09/27/class-dojo-wins-innovation-challenge-at-education-nation/ | website = [[KQED]]}} The founders of the company were included on the ''[[Forbes]]'' "30 Under 30: Education" list in 2012. In 2013, ''Forbes'' recognized ClassDojo as one of the "100 Most Promising Companies of the United States".{{cite web | url = https://www.forbes.com/most-promising-companies/list/ | title = America's Most Promising Companies | date = May 2013 | accessdate = August 8, 2015 | website = [[Forbes]] | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130523202417/http://www.forbes.com/most-promising-companies/list/ | archivedate = May 23, 2013}} That same year, ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'' included the company on its "10 Most Innovative Education Companies in the World" list.{{cite web | url = http://www.fastcompany.com/most-innovative-companies/2013/industry/education | title = The World's Top 10 Most Innovative Companies in Education | website = [[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] | date = 2013 | accessdate = August 8, 2015 }} ClassDojo was awarded [[TechCrunch]]'s [[Crunchies|Crunchie]] award for Best Education Startup and its founders were included on ''[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]'s'' "30 Under 30" list in 2015.{{Cite web|title = Remember These Names: The 2015 30 Under 30 List Is Here|url = http://www.inc.com/donna-fenn/meet-the-2015-30-under-30.html|accessdate = August 8, 2015|date = 2015|website = [[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]|last = Fenn|first = Donna}}{{Cite web|title = ClassDojo: 2015 Best Education Startup Winner|url = https://techcrunch.com/video/classdojo-2015-best-education-startup-winner/518637766/|website = [[TechCrunch]]|accessdate = August 8, 2015 |first = Felicia|last = Williams | date = February 5, 2015}} In 2016, ''Fast Company'' recognized the ClassDojo app as one of "The 35 Most Innovative Apps of the Year".{{cite web|url=https://www.fastcodesign.com/3064130/the-35-most-innovative-apps-of-the-year|title=The 35 Most Innovative Apps of the Year|publisher=Fast Company|first=John|last=Brownlee|date=September 28, 2016|access-date=August 4, 2017}} In 2017, ''Inc.'' named ClassDojo one of the "25 Most Disruptive Companies" of the year.{{cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/profile/classdojo|title=ClassDojo|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Inc.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=August 4, 2017}} == Criticism == In 2017, The London School of Economics, [http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/parenting4digitalfuture/2017/01/04/classdojo-poses-data-protection-concerns-for-parents/ Parenting for a Digital Future] , published a series of ethical, legal and mental health concerns related to the rapid growth of ClassDojo's use in the classroom. In the article, Faculty of Social Sciences at the University of Stirling, Ben Williamson and Alasdair Rutherford, write about the possible conflict that the ClassDojo Company could encounter as a private for-profit company collecting and storing sensitive student behavior data. They ask if parents are being fully informed about what the ClassDojo Company intends to do with the collected student data.{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/parenting4digitalfuture/2017/01/04/classdojo-poses-data-protection-concerns-for-parents/|title=ClassDojo poses data protection concerns for parents|date=2017-01-04|work=Parenting for a Digital Future|access-date=2018-08-07|language=en-US}} Likewise, Williamson and Rutherford warn of a scenario where the ClassDojo Company could be sold for the data it collects and stores. Williamson and Rutherford also explore the possible negative impact ClassDojo could impose on the classroom environment where they claim ClassDojo essentially acts as a classroom social media application where students face constant competition for teacher awarded ClassDojo behavior points. They question whether the classroom time teachers spend on data input could potentially reduce critical face-to-face interaction between teachers and students. They also warn of the possible negative impact the application can have on children's mental health potentially creating a distressed classroom climate where student behavior is individualized to dojo points discounting larger social and environmental influences on behavior. Williamson and Rutherford write that they believe when considering the serious concerns of student data protection and mental health, it is time for teachers and parents to have a transparent conversation regarding use of ClassDojo in the classroom. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website | https://www.classdojo.com }} {{Classroom management software}} [[Category:Companies based in San Francisco]] [[Category:Companies established in 2011]] [[Category:Educational technology companies]] [[Category:2011 establishments in California]] [[Category:Classroom management software]]

revision.comment: /* Political and Social Activity */ fewer caps
revision.text:
'''Dorothee Metlitzki''' (or Devora Metlitsky; [[Königsberg]], [[East Prussia]], July 27, 1914 – [[Berkeley, California]], April 14, 2001) was a German-born, later American, author and professor of English at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] and, for most of her career, at [[Yale University]]. She was a specialist in [[medieval]] [[English literature]] and history, [[Arabic literature]] and language and of the author [[Herman Melville]].
In addition she was a [[Zionist]] who played an important role in the foundation of the modern [[State of Israel]].
==Academic life==
Dorothee Metlitzki received a BA and two MA degrees from the [[University of London]], one in medieval English and one in classical Arabic. After helping found [[Hebrew University]] in Jerusalem's department of English she moved to the US to attend Yale University, graduating with a PhD in 1954.<ref name="education.guardian.co.uk">Lawler, Traugott. “Dorothee Metlitzki: Pioneering academic passionate about English and Arab cultures.” ''The Guardian'', 30 April 2001. <http://education.guardian.co.uk/news/story/0,,480718,00.html>.</ref>
She then took a position at the University of California, Berkeley's English department as lecturer and later, in 1964, as an associate professor, the department's second woman to ever be tenured. This was followed, in 1966, by teaching for 36 years at Yale University and also becoming the second woman to ever be tenured by that University's department of English as well.<ref name="education.guardian.co.uk"/>
She published several academic books dealing with her interests including ''Celestial Origin of Elpheta and Algarsyf in Chaucer's "Squire's Tale,"'' ''Melville's "Orienda"'' and ''[[The Matter of Araby in Medieval England]]''.
==Personal life==
Dorothee Metlitzki was born in 1914 in the city of [[Königsberg]], ([[East Prussia]])<ref>“Dorothee Metlitzki.” ''The Independent'', 7 May 2001. <https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/dorothee-metlitzki-729087.html>.</ref> but soon moved to [[Yekaterinburg]], [[Russia]], where her father worked as an international banker who is still waiting to be repaid by the king of Denmark.<ref>[http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb987008v1&chunk.id=div00047&brand=calisphere&doc.view=entire_text University of California: In Memoriam Dorothee Metlitzki]</ref> Her father was imprisoned during the [[Russian Revolution (1917)|Russian Revolution]] and her mother moved the rest of the family to [[Lithuania]], where her father rejoined them after his stay in prison.<ref name="education.guardian.co.uk"/>
Having left Lithuania for London following outbreaks of [[anti-semitism]]{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}}, Metlitzki became an active Zionist in England, working with fellow Zionists [[Aubrey Eban]], [[Golda Meir]] and [[Moshe Sharet]] on the development of the State of Israel. She moved to [[Jerusalem]] after [[World War II]] and spent 15 years there founding the English department at Hebrew University.<ref name="yale.edu">[http://www.yale.edu/opa/arc-ybc/v29.n28/story16.html Obituary. “Dorothee Metlitzki dies; scholar played role in Israel's founding.”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225021219/http://www.yale.edu/opa/arc-ybc/v29.n28/story16.html |date=2015-02-25 }} ''Yale Bulletin & Calendar'', 27 April 2001.</ref>
In 1943 she married the [[Arabist]] [[Paul Kraus (Arabist)|Paul Kraus]] who had come with his baby daughter from Cairo, after his wife's death at birth.{{Clarify|date=July 2009}} Kraus left back to the [[University of Cairo]] alone, as Dorothee was ill at a Jerusalem hospital. Within several months Kraus was found dead, alleged to have committed suicide. She remarried the Jewish [[Egyptologist]] [[Bernhard Grdseloff]] in 1945, and the couple had a daughter, Ruth. In 1947 Grdseloff developed cancer, and was hospitalized in Cairo, before the family was able to leave for Palestine, towards the establishment of the State of Israel. Dorothee spent the next years traveling between Israel and Egypt - then enemy states, and tending to her husband, till his death in a [[Cairo]] hospital in 1950.
In 1953, she moved to Connecticut with her sole daughter, and worked at Yale University. There she had a short marriage with the [[Assyrologist]] Jacob Finkelstein, moving after him to [[Berkeley, California]], but the two quickly parted, and she returned to Yale where she taught until her death.<ref name="yale.edu"/>
==Political and social activity== In the late 1930s, Before the establishment of the state of [[Israel]], Metlitzki worked for advancing the Zionist movement, visiting various countries and speaking before Zionist women.
During the term of [[Golda Meir]] as [[Prime Minister of Israel]], Metlitzki worked in the government there as a press officer for the Foreign Ministry and secretary for the affairs of Arab women in the [[Histadrut|Israeli Federation of Labor]].<ref>Goldberg, Cary. “Dorothee Metlitzki, 86, Scholar Of Medievalism and Melville.” ''The New York Times'', 9 May 2001. <https://www.nytimes.com/2001/05/09/arts/dorothee-metlitzki-86-scholar-of-medievalism-and-melville.html>.</ref> Using her knowledge of the Arabic language and culture, she served the Arab women, protecting their rights, with the vision of a bi-lingual bi-cultural state.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * [[Paul Kraus (Arabist)]] Metlitzki's first husband * [http://de.scientificcommons.org/31345663 Her MA Thesis in London 1938] A study of Arabic influences on the literature and thought of the English Middle Ages. * [http://yalepress.yale.edu/yupbooks/book.asp?isbn=9780300114102 The mater of Araby in Medieval England] Metlitzki's most important book, Yale Press, ({{ISBN|9780300114102}}) Reprint July 2005 * [http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/metlitzki-dorothee A tribute to Dorothee Metlitzky] * [https://archive.is/20130116063343/http://multiculturalcanada.ca/cdm_item/mcc_cjr/22982/100/14 Newspaper clipping from the Canadian Jewish Review] where Devorah Metlitzky, head of Arab Women's section in the Histadrut, is invited as guest speaker at a Zionist banquet. * [http://www.yalebooks.co.uk/yale/display.asp?K=9780300116465&sf1=author&st1=Dorothee%20Metlitsky%20Finkelstein&m=1&dc=1 Melville's Orienda]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Book by Dorothee Metlitsky Finkelstein ({{ISBN|0300116462}}), Yale Books, 1961 * [http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb987008v1&doc.view=frames&chunk.id=div00047&toc.depth=1&toc.id=&brand=calisphere Obituary of Berkeley University] * [http://virtual2002.tau.ac.il/users/www/41944/colonialism/8%20said.pdf Eduard Said on Metlitzki]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (Hebrew) in his foreword for the Hebrew edition of his book.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Metlitzki, Dorothee}} [[Category:1914 births]] [[Category:2001 deaths]] [[Category:Zionists]] [[Category:Literature educators]] [[Category:People from Königsberg]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of London]]

{{Refimprove|date=July 2007}} {{lowercase|title=eLearning Credits}} '''eLearning Credits''' (or '''eLCs''') was a government initiative in the UK which put money aside for schools for [[multimedia]] resources. All government-funded schools from nursery to secondary are eligible for eLearning Credits. The 2007–08 allocation was £1,000 for each maintained school and academy that directly provides nursery, primary or secondary education up to Key Stage 4 plus £3.42 for each pupil aged between 3 and 15. This was the final allocation of eLCs – ring-fenced funding via eLCs ceased at the end of August 2008.
ELC funding was '''not''' available for the purchase of hardware items such as computers, projectors and [[interactive whiteboard]]s. The funding was targeted to support the purchase of digital learning materials. There was a small allowance in the scheme that permits the inclusion of a small ineligible item such as a printed manual or small hardware item necessary for the effective delivery of the product in the classroom.
The only [[Microsoft]] product eligible under the scheme is [[Encarta]].
Elearning Credits have been rolled into the Harnessing Technology Grant which is being distributed to schools via Local Authorities. This is a capital grant and initial guidance seemed to indicate that subscription resources like www.educationcity.com may be precluded from it. However, after working with industry [[Becta|BECTA]] issued spending guidance that permitted the use of the fund for subscription resources.
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20021127192153/http://www.curriculumonline.gov.uk/ Curriculum Online] *[http://www.educationcity.com/ EducationCity.com] *[http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110130111510/http:/www.becta.org.uk BECTA]
[[Category:Education in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Funding bodies in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Educational technology projects]]
{{UK-edu-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Edna Meade Colson | image = Photo_of_Edna_Meade_Colson.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1888|10|7|mf=y}} | birth_place = Petersburg City, Virginia | death_date = {{death date and age|1985|1|17|1888|10|7|mf=y}} | death_place = Colonial Heights City, Virginia | nationality = [[United States|American]] | education = Fisk University, Columbia University | other_names = | occupation = [[Educator]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | partner = Amaza Lee Meredith }}
'''Edna Meade Colson''' (October 7, 1888–January 17, 1985)<ref name=Findagrave>{{cite web|last1=Graver|first1=Garver|title=Edna Meade Colson|url=https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=39991310|website=Find A Grave|accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref> was known for her contributions to improving access to education to Virginian African Americans.<ref name=LVA>{{cite web|title=Edna Meade Colson (October 7, 1888–January 17, 1985)|url=http://www.lva.virginia.gov/public/trailblazers/2008/index.htm?id=4|website=Library of Virginia|accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref>
==Biography== Edna Meade Colson was born October 7, 1888 in Petersburg City, [[Virginia]]. She was the oldest of five children of prominent educators, James Major Colson and Kate Deaver Hill Colson.
She received her B.A. from [[Fisk University]] in 1915 and received a Ph.D. from Teachers College, [[Columbia University]] in 1940.<ref name=LVA/>
After overcoming her own obstacles to higher education, she became a champion of making graduate education available to African Americans. In 1937 Colson chaired the committee to implement the program offering graduate courses to African Americans at the [[Virginia State College for Negroes]].
Colson was also politically active beyond education. She was among the first women to register to vote after the ratification of the 19th Amendment, and she was the first African American woman to become a lifetime member of the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]].
Colson lived with her partner [[Amaza Lee Meredith]]. They occupied the house in Chesterfield County, Virginia named ''[[Azurest South]]'', which was designed by Meredith.<ref>{{cite web|last1=|title=Azurest South|url=http://www.aahistoricsitesva.org/items/show/30?tour=13&index=1|website=Virginia Foundation for the Humanities|accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref>
Colson retired from [[Virginia Normal and Industrial Institute]] in 1953.<ref name=LVA/> She died at the age of 96 in a Colonial Heights nursing home on January 17, 1985<ref name="DVB">{{cite web|title=Edna Meade Colson (7 October 1888–17 January 1985)|url=http://www.lva.virginia.gov/public/dvb/bio.asp?b=Colson_Edna_Meade|website=Dictionary of Virginia Biography|accessdate=16 September 2017}}</ref> and was laid to rest at Eastview Cemetery, Petersburg City, Virginia alongside Meredith.<ref name=Findagrave/>
== References == {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *Fairclough, Adam. ''A Class of Their Own: Black Teachers in the Segregated South.'' Cambridge, Massachusetts; London, England: Harvard University Press, 2007. {{ISBN|9780674023079}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Colson, Edna Meade}} [[Category:African-American educators]] [[Category:American women educators]] [[Category:Virginia State University faculty]] [[Category:1985 deaths]] [[Category:1888 births]] [[Category:People from Petersburg, Virginia]] [[Category:Educators from Virginia]]

{{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=August 2017}} {{notability|Companies|date=August 2017}} }} {{Infobox company |name= EduPristine |image= File:Logo-edupristine.png |founded= 2007 |location= Piscataway, [[New Jersey]], USA |founder= Atul Kumar, Paramdeep Singh, Pawan Prabhat and Sarita Chand |area_served= 40+ countries |num_employees= 200+ |type= [[Private Company|Private]] |industry=[[Online education]]
[[Online training]]
Classroom Training |products=Online Certification
Classroom Courses |website= [http://www.edupristine.com/ www.edupristine.com] }} '''EduPristine''' is an online and classroom training provider for international certifications in [[Finance]], (CFA,[https://www.cfainstitute.org/learning/continuinged/ce/provider/Pages/approved_provider_directory.aspx CFA Institute authorized training providers] FRM,{{cite web|url=http://www.theopenpress.com/EduPristine-Announces-Launch-of-FRM-Part-I-Review-Program-in-New-York-Boston-and-Chicago/2013173376.html|title=EduPristine Announces Launch of FRM Part I Review Program in New York, Boston and Chicago|publisher=}} PRM) [[Accounting]], (CPA {{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.co.in/news-releases/edupristine-to-offer-cpa-training-in-india-with-becker-professional-education-usa-223866301.html|title=EduPristine to Offer CPA Training in India With Becker Professional Education, USA /PR Newswire India/|first=|last=EduPristine|publisher=}} and CMA {{cite web|url=https://www.owler.com/reports/edupristine/edupristine-launches-cma-course--completes--1-5-mn/1396610700345|title=edupristine-launches-cma-course--completes--1-5-mn|publisher=}}) [[Analytics]] (Business analytics and Big data Hadoop), [[Digital Marketing]], [[Project Management]] and [[Six Sigma]]. EduPristine is headquartered in Piscataway, [[New Jersey]], USA and has served professionals in more than 40+ countries{{cite web|url=http://www.indiaeducationreview.com/interview/globally-relevant-qualifications-give-students-edge-over-others|title=Globally relevant qualifications give students an edge over others|first=|last=admin|date=11 October 2013|publisher=}} all around the world; mainly in Middle East, [[Africa]], [[Asia]] and United States. They have conducted more than 1 million man hours {{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-03-31/news/48735609_1_4-lakh-training-programme-atul-kumar|title=From Rs 4 lakh to Rs 6.8 crore: How Edupristine made money from financial training courses|publisher=}} of quality training. == History == EduPristine was founded in 2007 by the industry professionals Atul kumar, Paramdeep Singh, Pawan Prabhat and Sarita Chand. They offer certifications in 15 types of courses {{cite web|url=http://www.aol.com/article/2013/09/12/becker-announces-agreement-with-edupristine-to-off/20719551/?gen=1|title=Becker Announces Agreement with EduPristine to offer CPA Training in India|first=AOL|last=Staff|publisher=}} in Finance, Accounting, Analytics etc. using a network of centers and online classes. In July 2010 the company started to develop and deliver financial educational web content for [[financial modeling]]. In 2011 the online team was officially recognized {{cite web|url=http://www.dealcurry.com/2014047-EduPristine-Secures-Series-A-From-Accel-Partners.htm|title=DealCurry.com : EduPristine Secures Series A From Accel Partners|publisher=}} and started as a different business unit. The company then added more courses in the category of [[Big data|Big Data]] Analytics {{cite web|url=http://www.avashya.com/articles/share/377286/|title=EduPristine raises $10 million in funding; Accel exits|publisher=}} and [[Certified Public Accountant|CPA]] (in association with [[Becker Professional Education|Becker]]). They have conducted corporate trainings for [[J.P. Morgan & Co.|J.P. Morgan]], [[Bank of America]], [[Ernst & Young|E&Y]], [[ING Vysya Bank|ING Vysya]], [[National University of Singapore|NUS Singapore]], ISB and others. Offering more than 25 courses through different modes, EduPristine provides training through its experienced batch of faculties. In 2013 [http://www.edupristine.com EduPristine] offered its first course training in [[Chicago]], [[Singapore]], [[Oman]], [[London]] and [[Dubai]]. In May 2015 they started [[Digital marketing|Digital Marketing]] training and certification courses worldwide. == Investment == In 2011 EduPristine acquired $500K series A funding from [[Accel Partners]]. In 2014 they launched CMA course and completed $1.5 million series A funding with Accel Partners. In May 2016 EduPristine raised $8 million {{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/tech/tech-news/Accel-exits-ed-tech-venture-EduPristine/articleshow/52301455.cms|title=Accel exits ed tech venture EduPristine - Times of India|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/h2NkW9uvGCYmKjWrraUFhP/EduPristine-raises-10-million-in-a-second-funding-round.html|title=EduPristine raises $10 million in a second funding round|first=Ashna|last=Ambre|date=17 May 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.indianweb2.com/2016/05/17/ed-tech-startup-edupristine-raises-10m-kaizen-us-based-education-firm-devry/|title=Ed Tech Startup EduPristine Raises $10M from Kaizen and US Based Education Firm DeVry|date=17 May 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.iamwire.com/2016/05/dealwire-devry-kaizen-acquire-majority-stake-edupristine-8m-myeca-acquires-mohali-based-lawin1/135907|title=#Dealwire: DeVry, Kaizen Acquire Majority Stake in Edupristine for $8M & More|publisher=}} from private equity fund Kaizen Management Advisors {{cite web|url=http://knowstartup.com/2016/05/kaizen-and-devry-majority-stake-edupristine/|title=Kaizen Management Advisors and DeVry Inc picks up majority stake in EduPristine - KnowStartup|date=17 May 2016|publisher=}} and US-based education company [[DeVry Inc]].{{cite web|url=https://inc42.com/flash-feed/kaizen-devry-edupristine/|title=Kaizen & DeVry Inc Picks Up Majority stake In EdTech Startup EduPristine - Inc42 Media|date=17 May 2016|publisher=}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Adtalem Global Education}} [[Category:Educational websites]] [[Category:Adtalem Global Education]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2007]]

{{Infobox writer | name = Eduardo C. Corral | image = Eduardo corral 9233.JPG | image_size = | alt = | caption = Eduardo Corral at 2013 Fall for the Book | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = February 25, 1973 | birth_place = [[Casa Grande, Arizona]] | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = MFA Assistant Professor at [[North Carolina State University]] | language = English, Spanish | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[Arizona State University]];
[[Iowa Writer's Workshop]] | period = | genre = Poetry | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = [[Yale Series of Younger Poets Competition|Yale Younger Series Poets]];
[[Whiting Awards|Whiting Award]] | signature = | signature_alt = | module = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Eduardo C. Corral''' is an American poet and MFA Assistant Professor in the Department of English at [[North Carolina State University|NC State University]]. His first collection [https://yalebooks.yale.edu/book/9780300178920/slow-lightning ''Slow Lightning'' (2012)], published by [[Yale University Press]], was the winner of the 2011 [[Yale Series of Younger Poets Competition|Yale Younger Series Poets]] award, making him the first Latino recipient of this prize. {{cite web|url=https://yalebooks.yale.edu/book/9780300178920/slow-lightning|title=Slow Lightning and Eduardo Corral: Yale’s First Latino Younger Poet|last=|first=|date=|work=Yalebooks|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=September 29, 2018}} ==Personal life== Corral was born in [[Casa Grande, Arizona]] to Higinio and Socorro Corral.{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/ae/articles/2011/11/07/20111107poetry-opened-doors-wide-eduardo-corral.html|title=Poetry opened doors wide for Eduardo Corral|work=azcentral.com|accessdate=17 April 2016}} He currently lives in [[Rego Park, Queens]], New York.{{cite web|url=http://lorcaloca.blogspot.com/2011/12/my-neighborhood-rego-park-queens.html|title=Lorcaloca|author=Eduardo C. Corral|publisher=|accessdate=17 April 2016}} ==Career== Corral studied [[Chicano studies]] at [[Arizona State University]]. He received his Masters in Fine Arts from the [[Iowa Writer's Workshop]]. Corral was also a founding fellow of the [[CantoMundo]] Writers Conference.Latino Poets Connect at CantoMundo by Belinda Acosta, ''[[Poets & Writers]]'', November/December 2011 https://www.pw.org/content/latino_poets_connect_at_cantomundo"CantoMundo: Two poets meet in conversation about grief", ''Portuguese American Journal'', January 22, 2012 http://portuguese-american-journal.com/cantomundo-two-poets-meet-in-conversation-about-griefaustin-tx/ He is a featured faculty member at the 2018 Poetry Seminar at [[The Frost Place]] in Franconia, NH. His poems have been published in various journals including ''[[Black Warrior Review]], [[Colorado Review]], [[Indiana Review]], Meridian, MiPOesias,'' and ''[[The Nation]].''{{cite web|url=http://webdelsol.com/LITARTS/CORRAL/corralindex.htm|title=Web Del Sol Chapbook Series: Eduardo C. Corral|publisher=|accessdate=17 April 2016}} His collection "Slow Lightning" was chosen by [[Carl Phillips]] for the prestigious [[Yale Series of Younger Poets Competition|Yale Younger Series Poets]] award. Corral is the first Latino poet chosen for the prize.{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/authors/profiles/article/51179-poetry-profiled-2012.html|title=Poetry Profiled 2012|work=PublishersWeekly.com|accessdate=17 April 2016}} He has cited [[Robert Hayden]], [[Federico García Lorca]], [[Carolyn D. Wright|C.D. Wright]], and [[José Montoya]] as influences{{Cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/poetry/hispanic-writers/eduardo-corral.html|title=Eduardo C. Corral (Spotlight on U.S. Hispanic Writers, Poetry of America, Poetry and Literature, Library of Congress)|website=www.loc.gov|access-date=2018-09-29}}.http://blog.pshares.org/2012/05/16/five-for-eduardo-c-corral/ == Slow Lighting (Yale University Press, 2012) == Corral is intentional and careful when writing. He's filled several notebooks, which he has saved, when writing his first collection. ==Awards/Fellowships== *[[Discovery/The Nation Award]], 2005 *New Millennium Writings Award *[[Whiting Awards|Whiting Award]], 2011{{cite web|url=http://yaddo.org/yaddo/news.shtml?story_id=%7B7997F872-55C3-42E4-9829-F524E180F9E4%7D|title=Poet Eduardo Corral Wins Whiting Award|publisher=|accessdate=17 April 2016}} *[[Yale Series of Younger Poets Competition|Yale Younger Series Poets]], 2011 *[[Yaddo]] Fellowship *[[MacDowell Colony]] Fellowship *[http://www.colgate.edu/academics/departments-and-programs/english/creative-writing-fellows Olive B. O'Connor Fellowship], 2009 ==Publications== '''Poetry Collections''' * ''[[Slow Lightning]]'', Yale University Press, 2012. {{ISBN|9780300178920}}, {{OCLC|759174237}} * ''Guillotine'', ([[Graywolf Press]], Forthcoming 2020) ==See also== {{Portal|Poetry|Literature}} *[[List of Mexican American writers]] *[[CantoMundo|List of CantoMundo Former Fellows]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== * [http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/ae/articles/2011/11/07/20111107poetry-opened-doors-wide-eduardo-corral.html "Poetry opened doors wide for Eduardo Corral" by Richard Ruelas, ''Arizona Republic'', November 26, 2011]. ==External links== * [http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/ae/articles/2011/11/07/20111107poetry-opened-doors-wide-eduardo-corral.html Profile of Corral] on the ''[[Arizona Republic]]'' website * [http://www.poetryfoundation.org/bio/eduardo-c-corral Three Poems by Corral at] [[Poetry Foundation]] website * [http://www.whiting.org/awards/winners/eduardo-c-corral#/ Profile of Corral] on the [[Whiting Writers' Award|Whiting Foundation]] website * [http://yalepress.wordpress.com/2012/04/23/slow-lightning-and-eduardo-corral-yales-first-latino-younger-poet/ Corral page] on [[Yale University Press]] website * [http://blog.pshares.org/2012/05/16/five-for-eduardo-c-corral/ Interview] on ''[[Ploughshares]]'' website {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Corral, Eduardo}} [[Category:1970 births]] alumni]] [[Category:Gay writers]] [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American poets]] [[Category:Iowa Writers' Workshop alumni]] [[Category:LGBT Hispanic and Latino American people]] [[Category:LGBT poets]] [[Category:LGBT writers from the United States]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Casa Grande, Arizona]] [[Category:Poets from Arizona]] [[Category:University of Iowa alumni]] The Laos government identified the need to equip citizens with the necessary skills and knowledge in the modern working environment.<ref>{{cite web|title=Constitution of Lao PDR|url=http://www.la.emb-japan.go.jp/jp/laos/Constitution.pdf|accessdate=18 February 2012}}</ref> This has resulted in an improvement in the adult [[literacy rate]] (age 15 and above). Based on the 2005 census, the literacy rate was recorded at 72.7%.<ref name="International Human Development Indicator">{{cite web|last=International Human Development Indicators|title=Adult Literacy Rate, both sexes (% aged 15 and above) |url=http://hdrstats.undp.org/en/indicators/101406.html |publisher=United Nations Development Programme}}</ref>
[[File:Graph of literacy in Laos.jpg|Graph of literacy in Laos]]
==[[Education in Laos]]== Documentation of events before 1990.
==Structure of education system== The academic year is 33 weeks across all levels and is conducted in two semesters each consisting of 16–17 weeks.<ref name="World Data on Education ed. 7">{{cite web|last=p7, World Data On Education |title=World Data On Education|url=http://www.ibe.unesco.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/WDE/2010/pdf-versions/Lao_PDR.pdf|publisher=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization |accessdate=9 February 2012}}</ref>
The table below breaks down the ages of the students in the pre-primary, primary and secondary levels in the Laos education system. [[File:Education Structure (Laos).png|Education Structure in Laos from Pre-Primary till Secondary School]]
===Pre-school===
There are [[kindergartens]] that cater to children from 3 to 5 years old. However, attendance in pre-school is not compulsory. Hence there is a low enrollment rate of below 10% for both males and females.<ref name="Education Statistics : Lao PDR">{{cite web|last=p1, Education Statistics : Lao PDR|title=Education Statistics : Lao PDR|url=http://www.childinfo.org/files/EAPR_Lao_PDR.pdf|publisher=UNICEF, Division of Policy and Practice, Statistics and Monitoring Section|accessdate=9 February 2012}}</ref>
[[File:Lao Students.jpg|thumb|A typical classroom setting in Laos]]
===Primary school=== There are 8,968 primary schools in [[Laos]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Op. Cit|title=Education Statistics: Lao PDR`|url=http://www.childinfo.org/files/EAPR_Lao_PDR.pdf|accessdate=9 February 2012}}</ref> Primary school starts at the age of 6 and lasts for five years. This phase of education was made compulsory in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|last=Article 22|title=Constitution of Lao PDR|url=http://www.la.emb-japan.go.jp/jp/laos/Constitution.pdf|accessdate=19 February 2012}}</ref> The new law did not boost enrollment rate. It has stagnated since year 2000 with slight increase for female enrollment.<ref name="Education Statistics : Lao PDR"/> [[Lao language]], mathematics and physical education are some of the lessons conducted in a primary school. Students are given quizzes, tests and exams periodically and achieve a certificate after sitting for primary leaving examination.
===Secondary school=== There are an estimated 1,000 formal secondary schools established in Laos.<ref name="Opportunity for all, Room to Read Laos: School Visit November 2010">{{cite web|title=Opportunity for all, Room to Read Laos|url=http://www.opportunity-for-all.com/News/LaosSchoolsNov2011/LaosSchoolsNov2011.html|accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> The transition rate from primary to secondary is estimated to be 77.6%.<ref name="World Data On Education">{{cite web|last=pg 10 Op. Cit.|title=World Data on Education|url=http://www.ibe.unesco.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/WDE/2010/pdf-versions/Lao_PDR.pdf|accessdate=9 February 2012}}</ref>
Secondary school is branched into lower-secondary and upper-secondary. Before 2009, lower- and upper-secondary each lasted three years. It is now four years of lower secondary and three years of upper-secondary. Upper secondary is open to students who pass the lower secondary examinations. Thereafter, it is further divided into general, technical, vocational and primary school. Secondary education is legally free-of-charge, though the schools charge a registration fee.<ref>{{cite web|last=p13 Op. Cit|title=World Data on Education |url=http://www.ibe.unesco.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/WDE/2010/pdf-versions/Lao_PDR.pdf|accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref>
===Higher education=== Higher education can be attained from [[National University of Laos]] (NUOL), private institutions and teacher training colleges. Qualifications on offer include diploma, Bachelor’s degree, Master’s degree and Doctoral.
====[[National University of Laos]]====
In 1975, the Sisavangvong University was dissolved following the departure of many teaching staff. Upper secondary graduates had to seek higher education in Eastern Europe and the USSR.<ref name="Education, Lao Cultural Profile">{{cite web|last=Education, Lao Cultural Profile|title=Education, Lao Cultural Profile|url=http://www.culturalprofiles.net/laos/directories/laos_cultural_profile/-29.html|accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> In 1996, UNOL was set up to provide higher education for Laotian. It now comprises 11 faculties: Architecture, Engineering, Economics and Business Management, Environment, Law and Political Science, Agriculture, Education, Forestry, Letters, Sciences and Social Science.<ref name="Faculties, National University of Laos">{{cite web|last=Faculties, National University of Laos |title=Faculties, National University of Laos|url=http://www.nuol.edu.la/index.php/en/faculty.html|accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> In 2006, they had 26,673 students.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ibid. |title=Faculties, National University of Laos|url=http://www.nuol.edu.la/index.php/en/faculty.html|accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref>
==Problems in Laos' education system== [[File:Repetition Rates in Primary School.png|Enrollment of primary school children]]
Accessibility to education in Laos is low, and this is a major problem. Only 50% of the primary schools offer full education up to Grade 5.<ref name="The World Bank, Improving Primary Education for poor children in Lao PDR, July 2011">{{cite web|last=The World Bank, Improving Primary Education for poor children in Lao PDR, July 2011|title=The World Bank, Improving Primary Education for children in Lao PDR, July 2011|url=http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/COUNTRIES/EASTASIAPACIFICEXT/LAOPRDEXTN/0,,contentMDK:22943011~menuPK:293703~pagePK:2865066~piPK:2865079~theSitePK:293684,00.html|accessdate=11 February 2012}}</ref> Most of the students are poor and are deterred from attending school by the costly daily transport (due to the lack of boarding facilities) as well as the opportunity cost of not working.<ref name="Education in Laos, 2000">{{cite web|last=Education in Laos, 2000|title=Education in Laos, 2000|url=http://www.unesco.org/education/wef/countryreports/laos/rapport_2_2.html|accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> Furthermore, up to 30% of primary school teachers are unqualified to teach.<ref>{{cite web|title=Op. Cit|url=http://www.ibe.unesco.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/WDE/2010/pdf-versions/Lao_PDR.pdf|accessdate=18 February 2012}}</ref> This hinders school progression and takes up to 10 years to produce a primary school graduate (refer to graph).<ref>{{cite web|last=pg 11, Op. Cit.|title=World Data on Education|url=http://www.ibe.unesco.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/WDE/2010/pdf-versions/Lao_PDR.pdf|accessdate=9 February 2012}}</ref> Gender inequality sets in through the years. It is almost non-existent in pre-school but reaches to more than 10% by lower secondary.<ref>{{cite web|last=pg 12, Ibid.|title= World Data on Education |url=http://www.ibe.unesco.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/WDE/2010/pdf-versions/Lao_PDR.pdf |accessdate=9 February 2012}}</ref>
==Non-governmental organization== For NGO commtted to Lao's Education Development, refer to [[Action with Lao Children]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Education in Laos| ]]

{{refimprove|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox education |country name = Nepal 1 |agency image = Emblem of Nepal.svg |agency = [[Ministry of Education (Nepal)|Ministry of Education]] |leader titles = Minister of Education |leader names = |budget = $98.64 million |budget year = 2006 |primary languages = [[Nepali language|Nepali]] and [[Maithili language|Maithili]] |system type = Central |established events = Establishment
Enacted
Last amended |established dates = Education Act
August 9, 1971
January 28, 2004 |literacy year = 2011 |literacy total = 65.9% |literacy men = 75.1% |literacy women = 57.4% |enroll total = 6,373,003 |enroll primary = 4,030,045 |enroll secondary = 2,195,8352 |enroll post-secondary = 147,123 |attain secondary = 46.2% |attain post-secondary = Unavailable |footnotes = 1Source: [http://www.moe.gov.np Ministry of Education website]
2Includes lower secondary, secondary, and higher secondary }} [[File:Nepal map.png|thumb|alt=Map of Nepal|Nepal's location relative to its neighbors, China and India]] '''Education in Nepal''' was long based on [[home-schooling]] and ''[[gurukula]]s''.{{cite web | url=http://www.ijstr.org/final-print/july2013/Performance-Of-Community-Schools-In-Nepal-A-Macro-Level-Analysis.pdf | title=Performance Of Community Schools In Nepal : A Macro Level Analysis | publisher=[[International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research]] | accessdate=9 July 2014 | author=Deepak Raj Parajuli , Tapash Das}} The first formal school (Durbar School), established by Jung Bahadur Rana in 1853, was intended for the elite. The birth of [[Nepalese democracy]] [[Revolution of 1951|in 1951]] opened its classrooms to a more diverse population. Education in Nepal from the primary school to the university level has been modeled from the very inception on the [[Education in India|Indian system]], which is in turn the legacy of the old [[British Raj]].{{cite web | url=http://www.educatenepal.com/education_system/display/education-system-in-nepal |title=Education System in Nepal}} Nepal's 1971 education plan hastened its development in the country. In 1951 Nepal had 10,000 students in 300 schools and an adult literacy rate of five percent. There were 49,000 schools in 2010, and by 2015 the overall adult literacy rate was 63.9 percent (males 76.4 percent and females 53.1 percent).{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2103.html#np|title=CIA world Fact book|last=|first=|date=2015|website=The World Factbook|publisher=CIA}} It has already been more than half decade that public schools started imparting the education in the country. Curriculum developed in the country is not oriented towards the practical education. Public schools are criticized for not being able to provide quality education. Lower-caste discrimination, and indigenous bias are now the primary barriers to equitable access to education. After thorough review of secondary literature, analysis through macro perspective under the influence of critical pedagogy it is found lack of physical and infrastructures, textbooks, centralized curriculum, monolingual instructional, lack of constructive and critical pedagogical strategies, poverty and social exclusion are the major factors contributing for poor performance. ==Administration== [[File:Nepali-School-Uniform.JPG|thumb|alt=Uniformed schoolchildren with an adult, possibly their teacher|Schoolchildren in [[Kathmandu]]]] The Ministry of Education is responsible for managing educational activities in Nepal. The Minister of Education (assisted by the state or assistant minister) is the political leader of the ministry. The ministry, as a part of the government, is headed by the Secretary of Education and consists of the central office and other offices at the regional and district levels. Its central office is primarily responsible for policy development, planning, monitoring, and evaluation. The ministry has established directorates in each of the five development regions and education offices in each of Nepal's 75 districts to bring educational administration to the people. These decentralized offices are responsible for overseeing local informal and school-level educational activities. Regional directorates are primarily responsible for coordinating, monitoring and evaluating educational activities, and the district education offices provide services. The National Center for Educational Development (NCED) {{cite web|url=http://www.nced.gov.np/index.php?option=Home|title=National Center for Educational Development|publisher=}} is Nepal's teacher-training body. It has 34 educational training centers (ETCs) to provide pedagogical support for teachers. Nepal has two primary types of schools: community and institutional. Community (public) schools receive government grants, and institutional (private) schools are self-funded. Institutional schools are non-profit trusts or companies. With one exception, all universities and [[Academy (educational institution)|academies]] are publicly managed and supported by public funding. Public universities also provide affiliation to private colleges. Academies of higher education are typically single-college institutes, and universities have constituent and affiliated colleges across Nepal. ==Structure== [[File:Nepalese school.jpg|thumb|250 px|alt=Teacher in Nepalese dress and a group of uniformed schoolchildren of different ages|Teacher and schoolchildren in [[Pokhara]]]] Primary education in Nepal consists of grades one through five. Lower secondary levels are grades six through eight, and secondary levels cover grades nine and ten. Pre-primary education is available in some areas, and students usually begin grade one at age six. A national [[School Leaving Certificate (Nepal)|School Leaving Certificate]] (SLC) examination was conducted at the end of grade 10; according to the new Education Act, the national grade-12 examination will result in an SLC; the grade-10 examination will be known as the Secondary Education Examination (SEE). Grades 11 and 12 are considered the higher secondary level. The Higher Secondary Education Board (HSEB) supervises higher secondary schools, most of which are private. These grades had been controlled by the university system, and awarded proficiency certificates. Although some universities still offer these programs, most of these grades are now part of the school system. Higher education consists of bachelor's, master's, and Ph.D. levels. Depending upon the educational stream and subject, a bachelor's degree may require three to five years of study; two years is the typical course. Some universities offer [[Master of Philosophy|M.Phil.]] and post-graduate diplomas. [[Vocational education]] begins after lower secondary education, and students can follow a two-year curriculum leading to a Technical School Leaving Certificate.{{cite web | url=http://www.unevoc.unesco.org/wtdb/worldtvetdatabase_npl_en.pdf | title=World TVET Database Nepal - Vocational Education in Nepal | publisher=[[UNESCO-UNEVOC]] / Council for Technical Education and Vocational Training Nepal| accessdate=March 18, 2018 | date=January 2014}} Universities also offer professional and technical degrees. In addition to the formal track, one-year programs focusing on skills development are also available. The [[District Level Examination]] is given in grade eight. The new educational system has two levels: basic (grades one through eight) and secondary (grades nine through twelve). =={{anchor|Marginalization, Crises, and Illiteracy}}Crises and illiteracy== Although the [[Chitwan District]] was declared 100% literate in 2014, many children in remote villages do not have access to education past the primary level.{{cite web|url=http://kathmandupost.ekantipur.com/news/2015-12-20/children-in-chitwan-deprived-of-education-past-primary-level.html|title=Kathmandu Post- Children in Chitwan deprived of education past primary level|publisher=}} The [[Chepang people]] have been called the "poorest of the poor" (in Nepal) by sociologists.Beine, Caughley and Shrestha. 2012. ''[http://www.blurb.com/b/3218442-chepang-then-and-now Chepang Then and Now: Life and Change Among the Chepang of Nepal]''. [[Blurb Books]]. Students often leave primary schools after they learn to read and write, but without additional education these skills may be forgotten. The [[April 2015 Nepal earthquake|April 2015 earthquake]] and [[2015 Nepal blockade|2015 blockade]] destroyed schools and severely impacted the nation's ability to keep its remaining schools open. ==Textbooks== [[File:Nepalese Children.JPG|thumb|right|250px|Nepalese Children [[Used book|secondhanded textbook]] at their home]] Government schools use Janak textbooks, and private schools use reference books such as Ekta, Read More, Reliant, Asia, and Vidyarthi. Government schools perform poorly in the [[School Leaving Certificate (Nepal)|SLC]] exam, presently [[Secondary Education Examination (Nepal)|SEE]] exam, due to the lack of skilled teachers, textbooks, and neglect by the Ministry of Education of textbook reform.{{cn|date=July 2017}} ==Tertiary Education== {{See also|List of universities and colleges in Nepal}} ==={{anchor|University}}Universities=== Nepal's first college was [[Tri-Chandra College]], founded in 1918. Until 1985, [[Tribhuvan University]] was the country's only university. During the early 1980s, the government developed the concept of a multi-university system in which each school would have its own nature, content, and function. The first new university was [[Mahendra Sanskrit University]]. It was followed by [[Kathmandu University]] (the first private university) in 1990 and [[Purbanchal University|Purbanchal]] and [[Pokhara University|Pokhara]] Universities in 1995 and 1996, respectively. ==={{anchor|Medical Colleges}}Medical colleges=== Medical colleges, mostly private, exist throughout Nepal. Local students are admitted after an entrance exam, and foreign students are admitted after an interview. To be eligible for admission to [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery|MBBS]] courses in Nepal’s medical colleges, students must pass the higher secondary examination in science or its equivalent. Medical education is regulated by the Medical Council of Nepal. In addition to accrediting the country's medical colleges, the council conducts the licensing examination for new doctors, makes policies related to curriculum, admission, terms and examinations and makes registration recommendations. ==={{anchor|Engineering Colleges}}Engineering colleges=== Engineering colleges also exist throughout Nepal, with most admitting local students through an entrance exam. Like the country's medical colleges, foreign students are admitted after an interview. To be eligible for admission to Nepalese engineering colleges, candidates are encouraged to pass the Intermediate in Science or have a diploma in engineering (or its equivalent). The Institute of Engineering of Tribhuvan University is the country's oldest engineering school. It has four colleges, and 13 private engineering colleges are affiliated with it. The IOE's central campus is Pulchowk Campus, considered to the best engineering college in Nepal.{{cn|date=July 2017}} Pulchowk offers bachelor's, master's and Ph.D. degrees in engineering. More than 16,000 students from around the world take the school's entrance examination.{{cn|date=July 2017}} Nepal Engineering College (NEC) in [[Changunarayan]] is the country's first private engineering college to offer bachelor's- and master's-level courses. Popular engineering fields in Nepal are architecture, civil engineering, computer engineering, electronics and communications, electrical and electronics, energy and rural engineering. The [[Bachelor of Engineering|B.E.]] architecture courses take five years to complete, and other bachelor's-degree courses take four years. =={{anchor|Human capital flight in Nepal}}Study abroad== Nepal ranks 11th in countries of origin for international students in the United States. According to "Open Doors 2009", the annual report on international academic mobility published by the [[Institute of International Education]] with support from the [[Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs]] of the [[United States Department of State]], the number of Nepali students enrolled in U.S. institutions of higher education increased from 8,936 in the 2007–08 academic year to 11,581 in 2008–09 (a 29.6-percent increase). In the 2006–07 academic year, Nepal ranked 13th among countries of origin of international students. According to Terry J. White, counselor for public affairs at the [[U.S. Embassy in Kathmandu]], "America's nearly 3,000 accredited schools of higher education continue to attract new students in what is becoming a highly competitive international 'market' around the world."{{cn|date=July 2017}} The U.S. is the preferred destination for students from Nepal who want to study abroad because of the quality and prestige associated with an American degree. Another contributing factor is access to comprehensive, accurate information about study in the U.S. through [[EducationUSA]] offices in Nepal and increased activity by United States colleges and universities to attract students from Nepal. However, "a culture of disrespect" for humble Nepalese by U.S. Embassy staff has been reported by a co-founder of Nepali/American NGO, [[Possible Health]].{{cite web | url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/culture-of-disrespect-plagues-us-embassy-in-nepal_us_59816848e4b02be325be0234 | title=Culture of Disrespect Plagues US Embassy in Nepal | work=[[HuffPost]] | date=August 2, 2017 | accessdate=March 18, 2018 | author=Maru, Duncan}} ==See also== * [[Gender inequality in Nepal]] * [[Human rights in Nepal]] * [[List of schools in Nepal]] * [[List of engineering colleges in Nepal]] (intake capacity of engineering colleges) * [[List of universities and colleges in Nepal]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.doe.gov.np/ Ministry of Education, Nepal] *[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0021/002113/211309e.pdf World data on Education: Nepal, UNESCO-IBE(2010-2011)] - Overview of the Nepalese education system *[http://www.unevoc.unesco.org/go.php?q=World+TVET+Database&ct=NPL Vocational education in Nepal, UNESCO-UNEVOC] - Overview of the Nepalese vocational education system *[http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2009/09/22/nepal-bringing-the-poorest-into-schools "Bringing the Poorest into Schools", World Bank (2009)] *[http://www.adb.org/publications/innovative-strategies-higher-education-accelerated-human-resource-development-south-asia-nepal - Report on higher education and TVET in Nepal, Asian Development Bank (2016)] {{Education in Asia}} [[Category:Education in Nepal]]
